Configuring Qlik BI software to work with Xcalar

The following task assumes that Qlik Sense or QlikView is installed and that the Xcalar user authentication is configured. For more information on how to install Qlik Sense or QlikView and configure user authentication, see the Qlik documentation.

Configuring Qlik Sense to work with Xcalar

This section describes how to create a connection between Xcalar and Qlik Sense and how to view your Xcalar tables.

Creating a data connection in Qlik Sense

To create a data connection in Qlik Sense:

  1. Log in to Qlik Sense as a valid Xcalar user.
  2. Open the Script Editor and click Create New Connection.

    3. The New Connection type window opens.

  3. From the Data Sources list, select Apache Spark (Beta).
  4. In the Server Type field, enter Spark Thrift Server.
  5. In the Hostname field, enter the hostname or IP address of the Xcalar cluster.
  6. Verify that the entry value of the Port field is 10000.
  7. Leave the Database value as blank.
  8. From the Authentication list, select Username and Password.

    9. Based on this selection the Username and Password fields are made editable.

  9. In the Username field, enter a valid Xcalar user name.
  10. In the Password field, enter the password for the valid Xcalar user name.
  11. (Optional) If you require a secure internet connection:

    12. In the SSL Options section:

    1. Select the Require SSL check box.
    2. In the Trusted Certificate field, enter the full path and name of the PEM file of your SSL certificate.
    3. Select the Allow Common Name Host Name Mismatch check box.
    4. If selected, deselect all other check boxes.
  12. In the Thrift selection field, enter SASL.
  13. Leave all other default selections as is.
  14. (Optional) Test the connection.
  15. In the Name field, enter a name for the connection.
  16. Click Create.

Viewing Xcalar tables in Qlik Sense

  1. Log in to Qlik Sense as a valid Xcalar user.
  2. From the DATA CONNECTIONS section, select the name of the connection you created between Xcalar and Qlik Sense.

    3. The Select Data modal window opens.

  3. From the list of tables, select the table's check box .
  4. (Optional) To specify specific columns in each table, re-select the table and then select the columns you require.
  5. Click Load and Finish.

    6. The Select Data modal window closes and the Data Loading modal window opens.

  6. Click Edit the Sheet and begin creating your reports.

For more information, see the Qlik Sense documentation.

Configuring QlikView to work with Xcalar

Before you can connect to QlikView, an ODBC DSN must be created that contains connection credentials, which is usually completed as part of the ODBC driver installation tasks. The following procedure is an example of how to create an ODBC data source name (DSN) using the Microsoft ODBC Data Source Administrator.

Creating an ODBC DSN

NOTE: The following instructions create an ODBC DSN using the ODBC Data Source Administrator modal window in Windows 10 .

To create an ODBC DSN:

  1. Go to ..\Control Panel\System and Security\Administrator Tools and select ODBC Data Sources (64-bit).
  2. Click Add.
  3. In the Create New Data Source window, select your ODBC driver and then click Finish.
  4. In the DSN set up panel of your ODBC driver set the following parameters:
    1. In the Data Source Name field, enter a name for this DSN.
    2. From the Spark Server Type list, select SparkThriftServer (Spark 1.1 and later).
    3. In the Host(s) field, enter the hostname or IP address of the Xcalar cluster.
    4. In the Port field, enter 10000.
    5. In the Database field, enter default.
    6. From the Mechanism list, select User Name and Password.
    7. In the User Name field, enter a valid Xcalar user name.
    8. In the Password field, enter the password for the valid Xcalar user name, and select the Save Password (Encrypted) check box.
    9. In the Delegation UID field, leave blank.
    10. From the Thrift Transport list, select SASL.
  5. Click SSL Options and in the SSL Options window do the following:
    1. Select the Enable SSL check box.
    2. Select the Allow Common Name Host Name Mismatch check box.
    3. Verify that the Allow Self-signed Server Certificate and the Use System Trust Store check boxes are deselected.
    4. In the Trusted Certificates field, select browse and locate the PEM file of your SSL certificate.
    5. Click OK.
  6. (Optional) Back in the DSN set up panel of your ODBC driver, test the connection by clicking Test. Do one of the following:
    • If your connection is successful, in the Test Results window, click OK.
    • If your connection is not successful, in the Test Results window, Click OK and verify your entries.
  7. Back in the ODBC Data SourceAdministrator (64-bit) wndow, click OK.

Configuring a QlikView connection with Xcalar:

To configure a QlikView Connection with Xcalar:

  1. Log in to Qlik Sense as a valid Xcalar user.
  2. From the menu bar, create a new view by selecting File and then New.

    3. An empty document opens.

    TIP: Close the Getting Started Wizard.
  3. In the empty document window, from the menu bar, select File and then Edit Script.

    4. The Edit Script modal window opens.

  4. From the Database list, select ODBC.
  5. Click Connect.

    6. The Connect to Data Source modal window opens.

  6. From the Data Sources list, select the ODBC DSN file you created, such as the one in Creating an ODBC DSN.
    7. TIP: To show all data sources, select the Show User DSNs check box.
  7. (Optional) To test the connection, click Test Connection. In the resulting Connection to Data Source Test modal window, click OK.
  8. Click OK.

    9. The Connect to Data Source modal window closes and an ODBC CONNECT statement is displayed in the Edit Script modal window.

  9. Click Select.

    10. The Create Select Statement modal window opens.

  10. View your Xcalar tables by doing the following:
    1. Select the Tables check box.
    2. From the Database Tables list, select a Xcalar table.
    3. From the Fields list, select the columns that you want to view for analysis.
    4. Click Add.
    5. (Optional) To select more tables and columns, continue steps a through d.
    6. When you are finished, click OK.

      7. The Create a Select Statement modal window closes.

  11. To save the script file, select File and then Save Entire Document.

    12. The Edit Script modal window opens.

  12. Browse to a location in which to save the script file, in the Name field, enter a name for the script, and then click Save.
  13. Click OK, which closes the Edit Script modal window.
  14. Select File and then Reload, which runs the script and loads the tables you selected into a QlikView dashboard.

For more information, see the QlikView documentation.
